newsitem.title: UK: UK PEP sales hit June record on windfall issues.
newsitem.headline: UK PEP sales hit June record on windfall issues.

text.p: Strong retail interest driven by a deluge of windfall share issues, pre-budget uncertainty and attractive returns pushed British Personal Equity Plan (PEP) sales to record June highs.
The Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds said PEP sales in June reached 649 million sterling -- up from May's 637 million and almost 70 percent up from June 1996.

"It is thought that the strong performance was due to a conjuncture of people receiving windfall shares and exchanging them for units or putting new money into unit trusts; a certain amount of pre-budget uncertainty over the future of PEPs; and a market continuing to offer good returns," Autif said.
It said unit trusts attracted 625 million sterling from private investors in the month, down from May's 665 million but up on June 1996's 450.8 million.
Total net sales of unit trusts to private and institutional investors totalled 841.6 million in June against 1.02 billion in May.
Institutional sales were lower in June from May and the previous June due to large outflows from the Far East excluding Japan and UK Smaller Companies.
Retail distribution rose to UK equity funds, while generalist international and oriental funds fell.
The net PEP sales of 649 million sterling brought to just under three billion the total for the second quarter -- by far the best quarterly showing yet.
